pros: The students are great to work with.

job_title: Job Title Withheld in Portland, OR
pros: Despite below, there are some people who try to do a good job. But.......
cons: The attitude there, implied and stated outright, is that they're an "exclusive club" of folks that should feel privileged that they were selected to work there. Because of this, nothing is above scrutiny. Honest mistakes due to miscommunication of staff are treated as if a cardinal sin has been committed. You can be fired for "not fitting in" to the group. The managers have no problem yelling at you for having the nerve to state your opinion, even if you're ultimately right. They have no issues making people schedule less breaks, enticing you into thinking you get a longer lunch; when, in fact, you're giving up a mandated break period. They have no problem staggering your hours so that planning anything regular in your life is impossible.

review_title: Bad pay, dead-end jobs, crumbling organization
pros: Co-workers are generally very nice. Excellent people overall.
cons: No raise for over 4 years, not even COL. No career progression. School is in decline overall. Wouldn't be surprised if it ceased to exist in the next 5 years.

job_title: Assistant Director of Counseling in Portland, OR
pros: I was never micro-managed by my boss, and the work setting and environment was enjoyable and attractive. Our department ran on a shoestring but still delivered exceptional service to students and stellar supervision to graduate interns (master-level counseling students from different schools).
cons: People were pleasant overall, and my boss and department were terrific, but the entire university seemed chaotic and disorganized. Decisions were poorly made and badly communicated, and the entire place seemed disjointed, and management styles were antiquated.

pros: I have no review at this time
cons: understaffing issues are rampant in the industry, natural medicine is no different

review_title: Good opportunity to earn money as a student
pros:
Students are welcoming. Majority of staff, doctors and professors are positive, curious, and encouraging to engage with.
Work hours very flexible for a student and pay is decent for this limited availability as a student. Some positions left time for studying while not engaged in greeting or working with others. You can network with others at times which may be helpful in schooling and future careers opportunities.
cons: I did not have negative experiences as a student worker there. Obviously it is temporary positions only for students. No other compensation.

review_title: Talk the Talk but don't Walk the Walk

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Portland, OR
pros: .... Not much to say. Is that five words?
cons: Insane place to work, poorly organized, etc

review_title: Be extra careful if you identify as a person of color
pros: Staff cares about the students for the most part
cons: Lots of favoritism and nepotism. If you're with the "in" crowd then you'll be safe from most things. If you're not than it can easily start to feel like you're being tossed around or taken for granted

job_title: Licensed Massage Therapist in Portland, OR
cons: This job is only for students as it is a work-study position

pros: Interesting subjects and knowledgable student body
cons: No much faculty togetherness, the pay is at the low end of the university scale

review_title: Great work-life balance and benefits, good environment, little opportunity to advance
pros: Very little expectation to work outside of business hours (I don't even open my email over the weekend!). They also have some unique benefits, like a Wellness Hour (one paid hour per week to use however we want, no requirements). Pretty much everyone says 'hi' when they pass in the halls and there is lots of participation in optional community events, whether it's a brown bag lunch lecture series or holiday cookie decorating competition.
cons: Low salary (relative to industry average and other schools in the area), with no raise over 2 years and essentially no possibility of a raise in the near future. Small size of departments/offices doesn't provide much opportunity for professional growth or advancement in role or title. Equity and inclusion initiatives are nascent, despite the left-learning/liberal majority.

pros: The benefits are great, which helps to balance out the low pay of academia, and the people there foster a genuinely caring sense of community.
cons: There is not a lot of room for advancement (people don't want to leave), but there is plenty of training and experience to help get a better paying job elsewhere when the time comes.

pros: The students, the patients  and the co-workers are all great reasons to work here. The mission is a motivating factor.
cons: Execs are disconnected from the rest of the staff and no one had had a merit based or cola raise in 2 plus years.  Benefits have been reduced and retirement plans all but eliminated. Tuition remission is a fake benefit. Only offered to full time employees

review_title: Pretty good place to work, salary, structure, job security need work
job_title: Coordinator, Digital Sales And Marketing in Portland, OR
pros: Community, values, lots of job changes/ad-ons available
cons: governance structure seems make-believe, lot of top-down stuff, salary and benefits seem to be the first things cut if needed, job security is almost non-existent

job_title: Scientific Writing Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: Passionate community made of many brilliant minds
room for growth, good benefits, great cause
cons: turnover, low pay, lots of politics
